text: The day I understood that speaking was a subconscious flow-oriented process and not a conscious process, completely changed the way I approached it. So instead of thinking tactics and frameworks and adding more to the outside of the things I need to think about, when I realized when I speak best, I'm actually not thinking about speaking.
speaker: Tristan de Montebello
context: Lenny asks Tristan about core principles that inform his approach to teaching public speaking. Tristan explains that the biggest breakthrough in his understanding was realizing that effective speaking happens when you're in a flow state rather than consciously thinking about speaking techniques. He emphasizes that the best speakers aren't focused on the mechanics of speaking but are completely absorbed in conveying their message to the audience.
text_ko: 말하기가 의식적인 과정(conscious process)이 아니라 무의식적이고 흐름 중심의 과정(subconscious flow-oriented process)이라는 걸 알게 된 날, 말에 대한 제 접근 방식이 완전히 달라졌어요. 그래서 전술이나 프레임워크(tactics and frameworks)를 더 생각해서 말하기에 관해 겉으로 뭔가를 더 얹으려 하기보다는, 제가 가장 잘 말할 때는 사실 말하는 것 자체를 전혀 생각하고 있지 않다는 걸 깨달았어요.
text_zh: 当我意识到说话其实是一个下意识的流动过程，而不是有意识控制的过程时，我的整个思路就彻底变了。以前我总想着各种技巧和框架(frameworks)，脑子里装一堆要考虑的东西，但后来我发现，其实我说话最好的时候，恰恰是我根本没在想着怎么说话的时候。
text_es: El día que entendí que hablar era un proceso subconsciente que fluye naturalmente y no algo consciente, me cambió completamente la forma de enfocarlo. Entonces, en lugar de estar pensando en tácticas y esquemas mentales (frameworks) y agregar más cosas en las que tengo que pensar, cuando me di cuenta de cuándo hablo mejor, en realidad no estoy pensando en el acto de hablar.
key_sentence: Speaking is a subconscious flow-oriented process, not a conscious process.

text: I actually think that the biggest misconception with tackling your speaking is that people grossly underestimate just how transformative it could be to your life. And the reason it's so transformative is because speaking is not a specialized skill, it's a meta skill.
speaker: Tristan de Montebello
context: Lenny asks about the biggest misconceptions people have about becoming a better public speaker. Tristan explains that people don't realize how life-changing improving speaking skills can be. He introduces the concept that speaking is a 'meta skill' - meaning that getting better at speaking improves many other areas of your life, similar to how fitness benefits extend beyond just physical health.
text_ko: 사실 말하기 실력을 다루면서 가장 큰 오해는 사람들이 그게 자기 삶을 얼마나 크게 바꿀 수 있는지를 과소평가한다는 거예요. 그게 그렇게 큰 변화를 만드는 이유는 말하기가 특정 분야의 전문 기술이 아니라 메타 스킬 (meta skill)이기 때문이에요.
text_zh: 我觉得大家对提升演讲能力最大的误解就是，严重低估了它对你人生的改变有多大。为什么说它这么有改变力呢？因为演讲不是什么专业技能，它是一种元技能(meta skill)。
text_es: En realidad creo que el mayor error que comete la gente al trabajar en su forma de hablar es que subestiman completamente lo transformador que puede llegar a ser para su vida. Y la razón por la que es tan transformador es porque hablar no es una habilidad especializada, es una meta-habilidad (meta skill).
key_sentence: People grossly underestimate how transformative speaking is; it's a meta skill.

text: People tend to self-sabotage a lot. I'm speaking, and obviously as I'm speaking, all of my senses are really, really heightened. So I'm aware of everything, if a word comes out a little bit weird or if it's not the word that I was expecting to hear come out of my mouth, I'm going to be very aware of that because I was expecting something and something different happens.
speaker: Tristan de Montebello
context: Tristan is explaining his third tactical tip about 'staying in character' while speaking. He describes how speakers become hyper-aware of small mistakes or imperfections during their presentation. This heightened awareness often leads to self-sabotage where speakers break character by commenting on their mistakes, even though the audience typically doesn't notice these minor issues.
text_ko: 사람들은 스스로를 망치는 경우가 많아요(self-sabotage). 제가 말할 때는 당연히 모든 감각이 아주 예민해져요. 그래서 사소한 것까지 다 의식하게 돼요. 어떤 단어가 조금 이상하게 나오거나 제 입에서 나올 줄 예상했던 말과 다르면 그게 훨씬 더 신경 쓰여요, 기대했던 게 있는데 다른 일이 일어나니까요.
text_zh: 人很容易自我破坏。我在讲话的时候，很明显我所有的感官都特别敏锐。所以我能察觉到一切，如果有个词说得有点别扭，或者说出来的不是我本来想说的那个词，我马上就会意识到，因为我本来期待的是一个结果，结果出来的却是另一个。
text_es: La gente tiende a sabotearse mucho a sí misma. Cuando estoy hablando, obviamente mientras hablo, todos mis sentidos están súper alerta. Entonces me doy cuenta de todo - si una palabra sale medio rara o no es la palabra que esperaba que saliera de mi boca, me voy a dar cuenta enseguida porque estaba esperando una cosa y salió otra diferente.
key_sentence: Self-sabotage occurs when heightened awareness leads to unexpected words.

text: If you start leaking and letting the insecurities come out, people are going to start thinking, this person doesn't really know what they're talking about. It's like a leader who isn't clear in their direction. Suddenly I'm thinking, wait, I think I have to second guess everything here because I'm not sure about this guy or this person.
speaker: Tristan de Montebello
context: Tristan continues explaining the concept of 'staying in character' by using an airplane analogy where a pilot unnecessarily worries passengers about potential problems. He explains how when speakers 'leak' their insecurities by commenting on their mistakes or expressing doubts, it forces the audience to view everything through a lens of uncertainty, similar to how unclear leadership makes people question decisions.
text_ko: 제가 조금이라도 흔들리거나 불안한 기색이 보이면, 사람들은 '저 사람은 진짜 뭘 아는 사람이 아니구나'라고 생각하기 시작해요. 마치 방향이 분명하지 않은 리더 같아요. 그러면 갑자기 '잠깐만, 여기 있는 모든 걸 다 다시 의심해야 하나?'라고 생각하게 돼요. 이 사람을 믿을 수 있을지 확신이 없으니까요.
text_zh: 你要是开始露怯，让人看出你心里没底，别人就会想，这人其实也不太懂啊。就像一个领导自己都说不清楚方向在哪儿，我就会想，等等，这人我得打个问号，他说的每件事我都得重新考虑考虑了。
text_es: Si empiezas a mostrar tus inseguridades y se te nota la falta de confianza, la gente va a pensar "este tipo realmente no sabe de qué está hablando". Es como un líder que no tiene clara la dirección que quiere tomar. De repente empiezas a pensar "oye, espera, creo que tengo que dudar de todo lo que dice porque no le tengo confianza a esta persona".
key_sentence: Leaking insecurities makes people second guess your knowledge and direction.

text: What we're trying to do is we're trying to internalize all of these habits to the point where I don't need to consciously think about them. So it's like a gymnast who's doing their tumbling routine and jumps into the air. As they're flipping, they're not consciously trying to think of how to do a flip.
speaker: Tristan de Montebello
context: Lenny mentions his struggle with not 'leaking' his insecurities after speaking exercises, and Tristan reassures him that this self-critical voice diminishes with practice. Tristan explains that the goal is to internalize good speaking habits so they become automatic, comparing it to a gymnast who has practiced so much that complex moves become subconscious rather than requiring conscious thought.
text_ko: 우리가 하려는 건 이런 습관들을 완전히 내재화(internalize)해서 제가 굳이 의식적으로 생각하지 않아도 될 정도로 만드는 거예요. 마치 체조 선수가 텀블링(tumbling) 루틴을 하다가 공중으로 뛰어올라 회전할 때처럼, 그 순간엔 '어떻게 도는 거지?'라고 의식적으로 생각하지 않잖아요.
text_zh: 我们要做的就是把这些习惯都内化，内化到什么程度呢？就是我不用刻意去想它们。就像体操运动员做翻滚动作，跳到空中的时候，在翻跟头的过程中，他们不会有意识地去想怎么翻，已经成了本能反应。
text_es: Lo que estamos tratando de hacer es interiorizar todos estos hábitos hasta el punto donde ya no tenga que pensar conscientemente en ellos. Es como un gimnasta que está haciendo su rutina de saltos y se lanza al aire. Mientras está dando vueltas, no está tratando conscientemente de pensar en cómo hacer el salto.
key_sentence: Internalize habits like a gymnast performing a tumbling routine without conscious thought.

text: The old way I think is shitty. I think it's broken, and I haven't found anything out there that is innovating on this. And it drove us crazy with Michael, and that's what gave birth to the Accordion Method. What's the old way? The old way is I have a talk coming up, so I'm going to dump all of my ideas on a piece of paper or multiple pieces of paper.
speaker: Tristan de Montebello
context: Tristan introduces the Accordion Method as an alternative to traditional speech preparation. He expresses strong criticism of the conventional approach where people write down all their ideas, rearrange them on paper, create detailed scripts, and then struggle to memorize everything. He and his co-founder Michael developed this new method because they found the traditional approach frustrating and ineffective.
text_ko: 솔직히 기존 방식은 정말 엉망이라고 생각해요. 근본적으로 문제가 있고, 이걸 혁신하는 걸 아직 본 적이 없어요. 그게 마이클과 저를 미치게 했고, 그래서 아코디언 방식(Accordion Method)이 탄생했어요. 옛 방식이 뭐냐고요? 강연이 다가오면 제 아이디어를 한 장 혹은 여러 장의 종이에 전부 적어놓는 방식이에요.
text_zh: 我觉得以前那套方法真的很烂，完全不行，而且我也没看到市面上有什么创新的做法。这个问题把我和迈克尔都快逼疯了，所以才催生了手风琴方法(Accordion Method)。那以前是怎么做的呢？就是我有个演讲要准备，然后就把脑子里所有的想法都往纸上倒，一张纸不够就用好几张纸。
text_es: La forma tradicional me parece una porquería. Está rota, y no he visto a nadie que esté innovando en esto. Nos tenía locos a Michael y a mí, y de ahí nació el Método Acordeón. ¿Cuál es la forma tradicional? Pues que tienes una presentación pendiente y te pones a volcar todas tus ideas en un papel o en varios papeles.
key_sentence: The old way is broken; it drove us crazy and gave birth to the Accordion Method.

text: Switch your mindset from what I want to say to what I want people to remember and limit whatever that is you want them to remember as much as possible and that's going to give you extreme clarity.
speaker: Tristan de Montebello
context: Tristan explains the core principle behind the Bow and Arrow technique for speech preparation. He argues that most speakers focus too much on what they want to say rather than what their audience will actually remember. The Bow and Arrow method involves identifying the single most important message (the 'arrow') and supporting it with compelling content (the 'bow') to ensure maximum impact and retention.
text_ko: 내가 말하고 싶은 것에서 '사람들이 기억하길 바라는 것'으로 사고방식(mindset)을 바꿔보세요. 사람들이 기억하길 바라는 핵심을 가능한 한 단순하고 최소화하면 훨씬 더 명확해져요.
text_zh: 转变一下思路，别想着"我要说什么"，而是想"我希望别人记住什么"，然后把你想让他们记住的东西尽可能精简，这样你的思路就会特别清晰了。
text_es: Cambia tu mentalidad: en lugar de pensar en qué quieres decir, piensa en qué quieres que la gente recuerde, y limita al máximo eso que quieres que recuerden. Eso te va a dar una claridad tremenda.
key_sentence: Switch your mindset to what you want people to remember for extreme clarity.
